Title.evidence: Continuous EEG Monitoring in Neonates with Congenital Heart Disease: A Retrospective Cohort Study

Participants.evidence: included infants with CHD who underwent surgery by 44 weeks gestational age and had cEEG monitoring

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the impact of continuous EEG (cEEG) background patterns and the duration of cross-clamp time and cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) on neurodevelopmental outcomes in neonates with congenital heart disease (CHD) undergoing cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was neurodevelopmental scores on the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development (BSID-III) at 12â€“24 months.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Longer cross-clamp time was associated with poor language composite scores (p = 0.036). Severity of encephalopathy during the 24-hour post-operative period was significantly associated with poor language composite scores (p = 0.026).

Harms.evidence: The study found a 100% rate of neurological abnormalities, with developmental delay and microcephaly being the most common.
